body:
The suite engine maps the annotations to the [Platform Launcher API](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/current/user-guide/#launcher-api). In this API there are two distinct operations, test selection and filtering. 

The `@IncludeTags` annotation is a filter. Filtering happens after all tests are discovered - which in this case woud result in an infinite recursion.

As a work around you could add `@ExcludeEngine("junit-platform-suite")` to keep the suite from discovering itself.

@marcphilipp I do suppose that when a cycle is detected we could also ignore the suite and quitely prevent the recursion.

issue.title: Stop further suite discovery when encountering a cycle

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

body:
> The suite engine maps the annotations to the [Platform Launcher API](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/current/user-guide/#launcher-api). In this API there are two distinct operations, test selection and filtering.
> 
> The `@IncludeTags` annotation is a filter. Filtering happens after all tests are discovered - which in this case woud result in an infinite recursion.
> 
> As a work around you could add `@ExcludeEngine("junit-platform-suite")` to keep the suite from discovering itself.
> 
> @marcphilipp I do suppose that when a cycle is detected we could also ignore the suite and quitely prevent the recursion.

I appreciate your response. When `@ExcludeEngines("junit-platform-suite")` is included, it works properly. I should maybe close the issue.

> I should maybe close the issue.

No, that's fine. I think you found something that can be improved.

rename.from: Caused by: org.junit.platform.commons.PreconditionViolationException: Configuration error: The suite configuration may not contain a cycle
rename.to: Stop further suite discovery when encountering a cycle
